document_title: Localized scleroderma: Causes, signs, treatment, prevention
subsection_content:
Localized scleroderma can last several years and then resolve without medical treatment. However, the disease can leave scars or areas of skin that are darkened or discolored... Until the condition improves, the patient should take appropriate treatment methods to effectively control symptoms. Below are some common methods often prescribed by doctors: (4)
Skin creams: Your doctor may prescribe certain Vitamin D creams, such as Calcipotriene, to help soften your skin. Symptoms often show signs of improvement during the first months of use. However, common side effects are burning, stinging and rash.; Corticosteroid cream: This cream reduces inflammation, but continuous use over a long period of time can cause skin thinning and many other complications.; Light therapy: For serious conditions and widespread damage, your doctor may prescribe light therapy.; Oral medications: For serious conditions and widespread damage, your doctor may also prescribe prescription medications. These are immunosuppressive drugs such as Methotrexate, Corticosteroid, Hydroxychloroquine, Mycophenolate Mofetil. Each of these drugs has potential side effects, so patients need to discuss carefully with their doctor before using to avoid unwanted side effects.; Physical therapy: If this injury affects the joints, physical therapy may be prescribed to improve mobility.
